prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong. The situation involves a girlfriend and boyfriend who live together. The guy pays all the bills because she only works part-time. The issue started when he asked her to pay for a $40 takeout because he forgot his wallet. She reacted negatively, which made him decide she should start contributing more to the bills.

First, I need to consider the dynamics here. The guy has been paying everything, which might be unfair in the long run, even if he can afford it. The girl works part-time, so her income is lower, but the guy acknowledges that her little income could be significant for her. The incident was about a small amount of money, but the guy is upset about her attitude. He's now considering making her pay some bills because of this one incident.

Is he in the wrong? Well, expecting someone to split bills when they have a lower income can be a big deal. If they're in a committed relationship, sharing expenses is normal, but it depends on their agreement. The guy might have been taking on all the financial burden without discussion, which could be unfair. However, the girl's reaction might also be valid if she feels taken advantage of. The guy is now changing the terms after one incident, which could come off as a power move rather than a fair adjustment. 

He's using a single instance to justify a larger change in their financial arrangement. That might not be fair either. The key here is communication. If they hadn't discussed how they were handling expenses, then both might have different expectations. The guy's resentment could be building up, but reacting after one event to make her pay more could be seen as inconsiderate, especially if her income is limited. 

So, considering all that, the answer might be A (the author is in the wrong) because he's making a significant change based on a minor incident without prior discussion, potentially ignoring the girl's financial situation. But I should also consider cultural norms and what's typical in relationships. Some people might think splitting bills is standard regardless of income, but others might see it as fair for the higher earner to pay more. The guy's frustration is understandable, but his approach might be abrupt and unfair given her part-time job. 

Therefore, the author is likely in the wrong because he's enforcing a change based on an isolated event without considering the existing financial setup and his partner's circumstances.
